DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Shooting Continues in Bucharest Early Saturday
DOC.TEXT: The AP's Mort Rosenblum was among the first Western journalists to reach the Romanian capital Friday night. The veteran AP special correspondent, who has reported from Africa, Eastern Europe, Latin America, and the Far East, filed this dispatch from inside the Romanian TV building Saturday morning just as it came under attack.

Fighting continued in the streets of Bucharest early Saturday, with automatic weapons fire erupting around the TV and radio studios that had been captured by opponents of President Nicolae Ceausescu. For all the joyous celebrations in the center of Bucharest on Friday at the ouster of Ceausescu, the mood on the capital's streets after nightfall was tense. All over town, there were makeshift roadblocks of buses, bulldozers, even bakery trolleys, testifying to the impromptu nature of the uprising. Army units supporting the popular revolt that forced Ceausescu from power battled on after midnight against pro-Ceausescu security forces. Just after 2:30 a.m. (7:30 p.m. EST Friday), heavy gunfire broke out around the television station, where occupants ducked below windows as shots rained toward the building. Lights went out as the gunfire pounded in. Minutes before the shooting began, crowds still were outside the TV building, chanting slogans in support of the popular revolt against Ceausescu. Gunfire also was heard echoing through the streets around the radio station about two miles away from the TV building. On arrival at the airport Friday night, a guard smiled at this correspondent and said: ``Welcome to Romania.'' When asked how things were, he replied, ``Now, it's OK.'' A woman customs inspector also seemed relaxed, waving visitors through with a big smile. Travelers from the airport to the Park Hotel in the north of Bucharest had to pass through seven roadblocks. At one, soldiers and police flashed ``V'' for victory signs and held up their fists in gestures of triumph. At another, soldiers sat with sullen faces in the scoop of a bulldozer. Bucharest residents appeared happy that Ceausescu had fled the capital, but were anxious as the fighting continued. The president's exact whereabouts were still unknown early Saturday. On Friday, he left his presidential palace by helicopter with his wife, Elena, but there conflicting reports in the hours afterward on his detention. ``Ceausescu is finished,'' hospital worker Alec Florescu declared with certainty. ``The people that are fighting now know that if they give up, they're in big trouble,'' said Florescu, whop supports the uprising. ``So they're fighting to the end.'' He branded the shooting of unarmed civilians in Timisoara last weekend and in Bucharest on Thursday as ``absolutely inhuman.'' An unidentified man said troops had shot his girlfriend in the arm Friday, but they were pinned down by gunfire as they tried to reach a hospital. ``They were just shooting directly at people,'' he said. A man who gave a Western reporter a ride through the darkened city, when asked what he thought of the situation, was more laconic. ``A small revolution in a small country,'' he said.
